BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. Gliding snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh wind slabs are in isolated cases prone to triggering especially on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. These can especially at their margins be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. The avalanche prone locations are easy to recognise. Caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.

A certain danger of gliding avalanches exists. This applies on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2400 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided as far as possible.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. Avalanche prone locations are to be found on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. These places are very rare but are difficult to recognise. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The weather conditions gave rise to increasing consolidation of the snowpack. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on near-ridge shady slopes at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. This applies in particular on shady slopes. Towards its base, the snowpack is faceted. The snowpack will be generally subject to considerable local variations.

Low and intermediate altitudes: Towards its base, the snowpack is moist.

Evening and first half of night: Over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area 40 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday above approximately 1800 m. During the day: Significant increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of new snow and stormy weather. On wind-loaded slopes more frequent natural avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, even large ones in isolated cases. Gliding avalanches are also to be expected, in particular on steep grassy slopes below approximately 2400 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Wind slabs are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. They remain for the foreseeable future prone to triggering in particular on steep shady slopes.
The wind slabs can be released by large loads in particular. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in gullies and bowls above approximately 2400 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of high temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack settled during the last few days. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. Fresh wind slabs have settled a little. Gradual decrease in avalanche danger as the temperature drops.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Wind and new snow above approximately 1800 m. The avalanche danger will already increase in the early morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The visible wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in particular on near-ridge shady slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence especially on north to northeast to northwest facing aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes. Whumpfing sounds and the formation of shooting cracks when stepping on the snowpack serve as an alarm indicating the danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular on steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A quite favourable avalanche situation will prevail. Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are in some cases still prone to triggering above approximately 2400 m. Wind slabs can in isolated cases be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in very isolated cases in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The avalanche prone locations are very rare but are barely recognisable.

In the regions with a lot of snow gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m. The weather conditions gave rise to increasing consolidation of the snowpack.
Evening and first half of night: Some snow will fall in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In particular in the north 25 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. As the day progresses as a consequence of new snow and stormy weather there will be an appreciable increase in the avalanche danger. The large quantity of fresh snow and in particular the extensive wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Older wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls above approximately 2400 m.
Avalanches can be released, mostly by large loads. In particular in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to rapid consolidation of the snowpack in all aspects. The older wind slabs are to be found adjacent to ridgelines and generally at elevated altitudes. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area wind and new snow. The wind will be strong to storm force adjacent to ridgelines. The danger of dry slab avalanches will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs represent the main danger. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas above approximately 2500 m and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack. Dry avalanches can be released, mostly by large additional loads, especially on very steep shady slopes.

In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Above approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. In particular in the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 1 (low) a little snow is lying in all altitude zones.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the last four days.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some localities a little new snow. The wind will be strong adjacent to ridgelines. The danger will increase a little during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Older wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls above approximately 2500 m.
In isolated cases the avalanches are medium-sized and can mostly be released by large loads. In particular in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to gradual consolidation of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A quite favourable avalanche situation will prevail. Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and older wind slabs are in some cases still prone to triggering above approximately 2400 m. Wind slabs can in isolated cases be released by a single winter sport participant and reach medium size. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released in very isolated cases in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The avalanche prone locations are very rare but are barely recognisable.

In the regions with a lot of snow gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m. The weather conditions gave rise to increasing consolidation of the snowpack.
Evening and first half of night: Some snow will fall in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In particular in the north 25 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. As the day progresses as a consequence of new snow and stormy weather there will be an appreciable increase in the avalanche danger. The large quantity of fresh snow and in particular the extensive wind slabs represent the main danger. Gliding snow requires caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs represent the main danger, especially along the border with France.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The more recent wind slabs can be released, especially by large additional loads, in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2700 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in gullies and bowls and in the vicinity of peaks. In some places wind slabs are lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to gradual consolidation of the snowpack. Below approximately 2200 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Above approximately 2500 m snow depths vary greatly at intermediate and high altitudes, depending on the infuence of the wind. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to significant settling of the snowpack in particular on sunny slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and the danger is greater.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Fresh wind slabs are to be found also areas not adjacent to ridgelines. Wind slabs can in some cases be released easily, especially on steep slopes above approximately 2200 m. At transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack the likelihood of avalanches being released is greater.
Isolated small and medium-sized dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of the strong northwesterly wind.
As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural activity of small and medium moist and wet avalanches will appreciably decrease.
As a consequence of new snow and strong wind the prevalence and size of the avalanche prone locations will increase in the evening.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area there is more snow than usual.
As a consequence of highly fluctuating temperatures and solar radiation a crust formed on the surface during the last four days.
Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
In the last five days on very steep grassy slopes several small and medium-sized avalanches occurred naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area wind and new snow. The wind will be strong to storm force adjacent to ridgelines. The danger of dry slab avalanches will increase during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be generally stable. From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are rather small and can be released by large loads in particular.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Hardly any snow is lying above approximately 1600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones hardly any snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be generally stable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are mostly small and can be released by large loads in particular. They are rather rare and are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to rapid consolidation of the snowpack in all aspects. The older wind slabs are to be found on north facing slopes and generally at elevated altitudes. Field observations show the favourable bonding of the snowpack. In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Up to 15 cm of snow will fall in the late morning above approximately 1000 m. Strong northwesterly wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be well bonded at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The surface of the snowpack has frozen to form a strong crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack is well consolidated and its surface has a strong melt-freeze crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The older wind slabs are rather small and unlikely to be released now.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Hardly any snow is lying above approximately 1600 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A generally favourable avalanche situation will prevail. Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs are in individual cases still prone to triggering in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The mostly small wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The weather conditions will give rise to increasing consolidation of the snowpack.
Evening and night: Some snow will fall in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In particular in the north 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday above approximately 1800 m. As the day progresses as a consequence of new snow and stormy weather there will be an increase in the avalanche danger. Fresh wind slabs require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular at low and intermediate altitudes hardly any snow is lying. Sunshine and high temperatures gave rise to rapid settling of the snowpack in all aspects.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A generally favourable avalanche situation will prevail. Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs are in individual cases still prone to triggering in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. The mostly small wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The weather conditions will give rise to increasing consolidation of the snowpack.
Evening and night: Some snow will fall in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In particular in the north 10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall on Friday above approximately 1800 m. As the day progresses as a consequence of new snow and stormy weather there will be an increase in the avalanche danger. Fresh wind slabs require caution.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Low, level 1.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Thus far only isolated small avalanches are possible. The small wind slabs represent the main danger. The avalanche prone locations are to be found at elevated altitudes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The more recent wind slabs have formed adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and generally in the high Alpine regions. They are very small and unlikely to be released now. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be severely restricted. These weather conditions will give rise to softening of the old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A generally favourable avalanche situation will prevail. Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs are small and can only be released in isolated cases. Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain, especially on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind. As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind, further wind slabs will form.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall. The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.
